Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She was scrolling through old photos on her phone, trying to organize them into folders - 'Beach Trips', 'Family Dinners', 'Home Renovations'. Her heart caught in her throat as she stumbled upon a folder named 'Us'. She'd forgotten about that one. The shame washed over her like a physical force as she remembered the fights they'd had over finances, his constant reminders of how much she earned compared to him. Each photo was a punch to her gut - their laughter now seemed hollow, their love tainted by unspoken resentment. She closed the folder, but not before noticing a half-written message from him in the chat bubble: "We need to talk about...", left unfinished when he didn't come home one night. She hadn't read it then, couldn't bear to. But now, she felt that shame like a heavy stone in her chest, wondering what they'd fought over last, whether it was something she could have fixed if only she'd tried harder.
Generated Assessment: I feel like there's this girl who's going to tell me things that'll make me hate myself. She said we're going to have some issues with our finances, and honestly, I'm just so done with everything right now. I don't know why, but every time I see her messages, I feel like she's saying things that are going to hurt me. She says she thinks I might leave her for someone else someday, and I can't help but wonder if that's even true. Is she really that smart? Does she always get it right? When I think about all those times we talked about money, it feels like I was already planning my escape. Every argument is just another step towards leaving her. Maybe I shouldn't be surprised; after all, she does say stuff that makes me want to quit, doesn't she? Like, remember that time she told me I wasn't good enough? That really made me want to give up, you know? And now, looking back, it was probably just her way of telling me she wants me gone. Why else would she keep pushing me away? It's funny, isn't it? When I look at pictures of us together, I feel like I'm seeing the same thing she's talking about. We were happy once, but now it just feels like she's been waiting for me to slip up so she can say "told you so." I don't know if I'm ready for that kind of truth

Triggering Event: He walked into his studio, the scent of drying oil paints still heavy in the air. The canvas before him was half-finished, the colors muted and dreary, mirroring his mood. He picked up his brush, but the weight felt unfamiliar, foreign even. His hand began to shake slightly, as if the very act of painting was now beyond him. He sighed deeply, the sound echoing in the empty room, and gently placed the brush back down on the palette. The solitude that had once fueled his creativity now seemed oppressive, a stark reminder of his loneliness. He turned off the lights and left the studio, leaving the canvas untouched in the gathering darkness.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, what the fuck is wrong with me? I can't paint anymore. Not since he left. The thought creeps in every time I pick up my brushes, but it's always so fucking far away, until I start moving again. Then, suddenly, it's there, this feeling of impending doom that anything I create will be a reflection of my broken life. I've tried so many times to get back to where I was, to recapture the joy of creating, but it's all been a failure. It's not just about the art; it's about the pain he left behind. Every stroke feels like a betrayal, as if I'm somehow betraying our relationship by continuing to live. What if I never forgive myself for staying here, for holding on to these memories instead of letting them go? I feel like an idiot, trapped in this cycle of guilt and regret. I've tried to fill the void he left with alcohol and distractions, but nothing works for long. I'm stuck in this rut, constantly wondering what would have happened if I'd made different choices, if I'd taken things further, if I'd stayed longer. But I know deep down that I'll never find peace here. This place, this studio, it's all tainted now, reminding me of everything I've lost. I don't want to think about him anymore, but every day, every moment, I'm forced to relive the past through my paintings. What if I never

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He noticed the clock hands creeping towards midnight as he sat at his desk, paperwork still piled high despite the late hour. His partner had left hours ago, but here he was, alone with the weight of the day's incidents pressing down on him. He felt a familiar twinge in his chest, a flutter like butterflies trapped behind his ribs. Breathing deeply, he tried to focus on the task at hand, but every sound from outside made him jump. His phone buzzed suddenly, startling him. It was a text from his partner's wife, asking if she'd seen him leave yet. He felt a pang of jealousy mixed with anxiety. Was tonight going to be another late night alone?
Generated Assessment: So yeah... I don't know what you're talking about. When did we agree that our partners' wives would start texting us at 10 PM? I thought it was just a nice gesture when they check in. Besides, I'm busy trying to get this work done. But hey, thanks for keeping me company. You know how it is when life gets hectic and we need someone to remind us everything will be okay. Just wondering why you chose this particular moment to reach out. Are you looking for some advice on how to make the most of your time? Or maybe you just want to chat about something else? Either way, I'm happy to listen. After all, that's what friends are for, right? So go ahead, share whatever's on your mind. I'll do my best to offer some helpful insights. We can even brainstorm ways to make tomorrow a little brighter. Who knows, maybe we can come up with something amazing together. Let's see where this conversation takes us!

Triggering Event: She noticed the clock on the kitchen wall ticking louder than usual, each second echoing like a drumbeat in her chest. Her husband was late from work again. She tried to focus on preparing dinner, but her hands trembled slightly as she chopped vegetables, knuckles white against the cutting board. The house felt too quiet, too empty. She glanced at the phone, willing it to ring, each unblinking second stretching her anxiety taut like a wire about to snap.
Generated Assessment: She had been looking forward to our anniversary all week, planning every detail. He promised to surprise me with something special, but when he walked through the door, he didn’t even say hello. Instead, he dropped his bag on the floor and began loading the dishwasher, moving straight into his routine. It wasn’t the romantic evening she had envisioned. Instead, she saw him as someone who always put others’ needs before his own, never considering how this might affect her feelings.

Triggering Event: She found an old photograph tucked behind her easel, of them laughing together at his art gallery opening years ago. The once vibrant colors now faded, like their love. A sudden, heavy sigh escaped her lips as she traced his smile with a trembling finger. She hadn't thought about that day in so long. The guilt of what followed crept back in, cold and unwelcome.
Generated Assessment: She had always known that she was the one who ruined it, but seeing him again made everything feel so much worse than she could have imagined. He had moved on to another woman; he was just fine, while she was left to carry the weight of her past mistakes. It wasn’t fair, and yet she couldn’t help but feel that way. Everything reminded her of him – every smile, every laugh, even the way people looked at each other. Every time she saw someone happy together, she felt a pang of sadness, wondering if things would ever be different for her. It seemed like no matter how hard she tried, she couldn’t shake off the feeling that she was somehow less worthy. Her life seemed dull compared to everyone else’s, especially those around her, whose relationships were so much more genuine. Even the small acts of kindness from strangers took on a new meaning when paired with the pain of being alone. It didn’t seem fair that she was the one left behind, especially after all she had been through. But deep down, she knew that this was her reality now, and she needed to learn to live with it.

Triggering Event: At his weekly poker game, Jack noticed his old partner's widow, now in her late 60s, quietly crying into her hands while everyone else laughed at a joke. He remembered the last time they'd all been together like this, before the shooting that had taken his partner and changed everything. His stomach churned with familiar remorse as he silently excused himself from the table.
Generated Assessment: Fuck, I can't even enjoy my damn drink anymore. It feels so fucking hollow knowing we're all just pretending to have fun while secretly mourning our fallen friend. They were supposed to be happy tonight, but nope - they're just sitting there, looking broken. Like it’s nothing, but it’s not. It hurts me too, you know? We lost him five years ago. I miss him every day. The memories still sting. Everyone was laughing and joking about his stupid joke, but I saw her... she looked so sad. I wish people could understand how much this means to us. We’re all trying to keep up appearances, but honestly, it’s killing me. Every time someone mentions something funny or good about him, I feel like shit. I want to tell them it doesn’t matter because he's gone, but deep down, I know they need this kind of support right now. Maybe if I talk through some of these feelings, maybe I'll finally start feeling better. But for now, fuck this stupid party. Let’s get outta here. **TL;DR:** Jack is upset because he sees an older woman crying after being reminded of the tragic loss of her husband, which also happened to be his best friend and former business partner. Jack cannot let go of the past and misses his friend dearly. Despite this, Jack wants to move forward and make new friends, but has trouble letting go of his negative emotions. ​

Triggering Event: She sat alone in her cubicle, fingers tapping mechanically on her keyboard. The office was quiet, most had left for the day. Her inbox pinged, an email from her ex. "Just wanted to let you know I'm seeing someone new. Thought you should hear it from me." She felt a pang in her chest, guilt gnawing at her. She remembered his voicemails, pleading for them to work things out. But she had been too consumed by work, too focused on climbing the corporate ladder. Now, she was alone, and he was moving on. Her eyes welled up as she typed a reply, "I'm happy for you."

"While restocking the shelves, he noticed a middle-aged woman trying to reach an item at the top. He offered assistance but fumbled the product, sending it crashing down, drawing stares from nearby customers."
Generated Assessment: It was so stupid of her to try reaching that high shelf by herself! She didn't know what she was doing. I mean, who tries to grab something that's out of reach? It just goes to show how careless people can be. The way she reached for it was clumsy; you could see she wasn't even thinking about grabbing the right thing. And then when I tried to help, I messed up completely. I'm pretty much useless when it comes to this kind of stuff. I should've never gotten involved. Now everyone's staring because of my clumsiness, and it feels like they're judging me. This whole experience is making me angry. Why did she have to try to grab something she couldn’t handle? If she hadn't been so stupid, none of this would’ve happened. This isn't the first time something like this has happened—she probably does it all the time, which makes me wonder if she’s always been like this. Maybe she’s just really bad at handling things. But honestly, why bother helping someone who doesn’t deserve it? I’m so annoyed with myself. I should be better than this. I get angry when people don't listen to reason or take responsibility for their actions. It’s frustrating seeing others make mistakes and not learn from them. I feel like I waste my time trying to explain things to people, especially when they’re clearly not listening. I guess some people are just meant to cause problems and distract others. When I tried

Triggering Event: In the staff room, she noticed a note pinned to her bulletin board. It was a parent's complaint about her teaching methods, signed with an ambiguous initial. She felt her cheeks flush as she read it, imagining the other teachers finding out.
Generated Assessment: I can't believe I'm still stuck with this job after all these years. The worst part is that my colleagues are starting to think I'm incompetent. I wonder what would happen if one of the parents sued me for negligence. Would I lose my position, and have to move back in with my parents? It's ridiculous; I've been doing just fine before that one incident. But now they're questioning my ability to teach, and it's making me feel so anxious. What if someone finds out about my personal issues and thinks I'm unfit to work here? I'll be fired, and I won't know how to support myself or my family. My boss keeps pushing me to improve my lesson plans, but I'm already working late nights. If I have to spend even more time at school, I might start skipping meals – which could lead to health problems. And then there's the possibility that the students will get upset when I'm tired, leading them to misbehave. I wouldn't want that to ruin my reputation or damage our school's good name. I really need to figure things out soon, but every time I try to change anything, I worry about the potential consequences. What if someone discovers my past mistakes and decides to sue me again? Or what if I make another mistake, and it gets reported to the authorities? My life could become a disaster, and I'd never recover from it. One day, while walking home, I saw a group of

Triggering Event: "A former student, now in college, messages her, 'Thanks for pushing me to take AP Lit; it's made my English major a breeze. You always knew I was capable of more than you gave me credit for.'"
Generated Assessment: This is so fucking weird! I'm like totally shocked she would say such shit about me. It's really dumb to think that she actually means this. She must've been bored out of her mind in class, because she wouldn't have remembered if I wasn't there. It doesn't make sense why she'd just magically remember all those times when she didn't even care back then, especially since I had to push her to keep her from failing. Anyway, whatever. If she's going to be this nice to someone else, maybe she'll give me an F next time. That way, I can get some real grades and show her how much I'm trying. But honestly, I don't want her to think I'm doing well anyway, because I am so much worse off than everyone else. Why does she always think I deserve everything? And what if she just forgot? Does she even remember we're in different classes now? Fuck. This is getting ridiculous. I guess I'll act like nothing happened... but seriously, I don’t know what’s up with her. Is she just being kind? I’m definitely not stupid enough to believe that.
